item.title: Hungarians Protest Orban Plans to Crush Civil Society, Media
item.description: Hungarians demonstrated in Budapest against Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s escalating campaign to muzzle critics less than a year before elections.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators protest a bill to cut foreign funding to civil society and media threat to Hungary’s sovereignty, in central Budapest on May 18.

item.title: Houthis Say They Plan to Target Israeli Airports in Coming Hours
item.description: Yemen’s Houthi rebels announced that they would carry out in the coming few hours military operations targeting Ben Gurion and other airports in Israel, in response to the Israeli escalation in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Mohammed Hatem

media:content.media:description: An El Al Israel Airlines and a HiSky jet at Ben Gurion airport in Tel Aviv, Israel, on Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024. Iran has said it wants to punish Israel for last week’s assassination of a leading Hamas figure in Tehran, but not to the point of starting a region-wide war.

item.title: China-US Trade Truce Prompts Nations to Consider Tougher Tactics
item.description: China’s defiant stance in negotiating a tariff truce with the US has convinced some countries they need to take a tougher position in their own trade talks with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump during a Congressional resolution signing in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 9.

item.title: Meloni Hosts Vance, Von Der Leyen for Trade Talks, Hails New Era
item.description: Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni hailed a “new beginning” in transatlantic relations as she hosted US Vice President JD Vance and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen to talk about trade, tariffs and security.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini

media:content.media:description: JD Vance and Giorgia Meloni attend a Holy Mass for the Beginning of the Pontificate of Pope Leo XIV, in St Peter's square in The Vatican on May 18.

item.title: Zelenskiy Meets Vance, Rubio Ahead of Trump-Putin Call
item.description: US Vice President JD Vance held talks with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy in Rome on Sunday at a time Washington is pressing for a quick end to Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini, Flavia Rotondi

media:content.media:description: Zelenskiy, center left, greets Vance at the inaugural mass of Pope Leo XIV in St. Peter’s Square in Vatican City on Sunday.

item.title: Israeli Strikes Across Gaza Kill at Least 103 People, Medics Say
item.description: DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — Israel launched “extensive” new ground operations in the Gaza Strip while airstrikes in its new offensive killed at least 103 people, including dozens of children, overnight and into Sunday, hospitals and medics said. The strikes forced northern Gaza's main hospital to close.

media:content.media:description: Search and rescue teams work under the rubble after the Israeli army attacked a building at the Jabalia Refugee Camp in Gaza Strip on May 18.

item.title: Ramaphosa Walks a Diplomatic Tightrope in Risky Trump Meeting
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa will meet Donald Trump this week after months of criticism from the US president, but some advisers fear he risks a Volodymyr Zelenskiy-style dressing down in the Oval Office.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa during the G20 Foreign Minister Meeting in Johannesburg.

item.title: Investors Await Another Monday Jolt After Moody’s Downgrades US
item.description: Investors face yet another bumpy start to the trading week, although it’s mounting concern over US debt rather than tariffs likely generating the volatility this time.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova, Carmen Reinicke, Anya Andrianova

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. US stocks were on pace to snap a three-day winning streak Thursday, driven by declines in technology, energy and retailers as traders assessed a slew of mixed economic figures.

item.title: French Regulator Tells Airlines to Cut Orly Flights After Glitch
item.description: France’s civil aviation regulator asked airlines to reduce their flight schedules at Paris-Orly airport by 40% by the end of Sunday after air traffic control systems suffered a failure.
item.dc:creator: Francois De Beaupuy

media:content.media:description: Passengers in the departures hall at Paris-Orly Airport, operated by Aeroports de Paris, in Paris, France, on Tuesday, Feb. 27, 2024. Air France-KLM report earnings on Feb. 29.

item.title: South Korean Election Favorite Sees No Need to Rush for US Deal
item.description: South Korea’s leading presidential candidate Lee Jae-myung said there’s no need to rush for an early agreement in trade negotiations with the US, criticizing the interim government for what he called a hasty engagement with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung Photographer: Woohae Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Bessent Calls Moody’s ‘Lagging Indicator’ of US Fiscal Health
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent downplayed concerns over the US’s government debt and the inflationary impact of tariffs on companies including Walmart Inc., saying the Trump administration is determined to lower federal spending and grow the economy.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: Clock Ticks on Hostage Talks as Israel Readies Major Gaza Sweep
item.description: Israeli officials say they’re poised to order tanks and troops into unconquered parts of the Gaza Strip in a bid to destroy Hamas, throwing an ultimatum at the Palestinian Islamist faction to concede on terms for a winding down of the war.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: This picture taken from a position in southern Israel shows Israeli tanks deployed on the border with the Gaza Strip on May 17, 2025. The Israeli military announced the early stages of an intensified operation in Gaza aimed at defeating Hamas, with rescuers in the beseiged Palestinian territory reporting 10 killed on May 17 in fresh Israeli strikes. (Photo by Jack GUEZ / AFP) (Photo by JACK GUEZ/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Iran Vows to Uphold Pursuit of Peaceful Nuclear Energy
item.description: Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian said his country won’t abandon its pursuit of civilian nuclear energy under any circumstances, while reiterating that Tehran has no intention of developing nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Bushehr province, Iran.

item.title: Libya PM Vows to End Militias As Protests, Violence Rock Capital
item.description: Libya’s prime minister vowed to rid the North African nation of militias as deadly clashes and anti-government protests sparked fears of a widening conflict.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany, Hatem Mohareb

media:content.media:description: Libyan armored vehicles patrol after clashes between heavily armed militias in Tripoli, Libya, Wednesday, May 14, 2025.(AP Photo/Yousef Murad)

item.title: China Gave Pakistan Satellite Support, Indian Defense Group Says
item.description: China provided Pakistan with air defense and satellite support during its clash with India this month, according to a research group under India’s Ministry of Defence, suggesting that Beijing was more directly involved in the conflict than was previously disclosed.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen, Dan Strumpf

media:content.media:description: A motorcyclist rides past shattered glasses of a restaurant outside the Rawalpindi cricket stadium after an alleged drone was shot down in Rawalpindi on May 8, 2025. India and Pakistan accused each other on May 8 of carrying out waves of drone attacks, as deadly confrontations between the nuclear-armed foes drew global calls for calm. Pakistan's army said it shot down 25 Indian drones, while New Delhi accused Islamabad of launching overnight raids with "drones and missiles", and claimed it destroyed an air defence system in Lahore. (Photo by Aamir QURESHI / AFP) (Photo by AAMIR QURESHI/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: UK, EU Wrangle Over Students and Travel Ahead of Reset Summit
item.description: British and European Union negotiators wrangled over measures to ease travel for students, young workers and tourists this weekend, as the two sides raced to resolve policy disputes ahead of a summit meant to reset their fraught relationship.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, left, and UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer meet last month in Downing Street.

item.title: ECB’s Lagarde Says Euro’s Strength Is Counterintuitive, But Justified
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said the recent rise of the euro against the dollar is a consequence of US President Donald Trump’s erratic policies and an opportunity for Europe.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Francois De Beaupuy

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde

item.title: Portugal Holds Third Election in Three Years: What to Watch
item.description: Portugal holds its third election in as many years on Sunday, after Prime Minister Luis Montenegro’s minority government lost a confidence vote in parliament in March.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida, Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Luis Montenegro, Portugal's prime minister, center, at a street rally on May 16. Photographer: Patricia de Melo Moreira/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Plans Call With Putin to End ‘Bloodbath’ in Ukraine
item.description: President Donald Trump said he’ll have a phone call with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday morning to discuss how to stop the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Whitelaw, Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks to members of the media accompanying him aboard Airforce One, after leaving Abu Dhabi at the end of his Middle East tour on May 16, 2025. Trump capped his Gulf tour in Abu Dhabi after signing another raft of multi-billion-dollar deals, while also securing a $1.4 trillion investment pledge from the UAE. (Photo by Brendan SMIALOWSKI / AFP) (Photo by BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Iran Sentences Three to Death Over Fatal Mosque Attacks
item.description: Iran handed death sentences to three individuals for allegedly participating in fatal shootings at the Shah Cheragh mosque in the southern city of Shiraz, the judiciary’s official news portal Mizan reported on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: Shah Cheragh mausoleum in Iran's southern city of Shiraz on May 14 ATTA KENARE / AFP) (Photo by ATTA KENARE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: India Restricts Some Imports from Bangladesh as Ties Suffer
item.description: India imposed curbs on imports of ready-made garments and processed food from Bangladesh, as relations between the two neighbors turned sour in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy

media:content.media:description: The land port restrictions may further affect the ties between the two nations as India was Bangladesh’s third-biggest trading partner in 2024.

item.title: Polish President Vote Tests Pro-Europe Government: What to Watch
item.description: Poles will vote on Sunday to decide whether Prime Minister Donald Tusk gains an ally in the presidential palace to complete his bid to undo years of populist rule.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: Campaign banners of Karol Nawrocki, left, and Rafal Trzaskowski, in Opole, Poland. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Canada Says Most Tariffs on US Remain, Pushing Back on Oxford Report
item.description: Canada’s finance minister said the government kept 25% retaliatory tariffs on tens of billions of dollars in US goods, disputing a report from a research firm that suggested it had paused the vast majority of those levies.
item.dc:creator: Derek Decloet

item.title: Trump Loyalist Faces Math Prodigy in Romania Vote: What to Watch
item.description: Romanians elect their next president on Sunday in a contest that will determine the Black Sea nation’s trajectory in Europe as frustration with the political establishment spurs a surge in support for the far right.
item.dc:creator: Irina Vilcu, Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: George Simion, right, casts his ballot beside former candidate Calin Georgescu on May 4. Photographer: Daniel Mihailescu/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Explosion Rocks Fertility Clinic in Palm Springs
item.description: The person believed responsible for an attack targeting a Southern California fertility clinic Saturday posted rambling online writings before an explosion that investigators are treating as an act of terrorism, according to a law enforcement official.

media:content.media:description: Law enforcement officials near the scene of an explosion in Palm Springs, California, on May 17, 2025.

item.title: Fatalities Climb as Tornado, Severe Weather Sweep Through US
item.description: LONDON, Ky. (AP) — At least 27 people have been killed by storms systems that swept across part of the U.S. Midwest and South, with Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear announcing Saturday that 18 of the deaths came in his state and 10 others were hospitalized in critical condition.

media:content.media:description: People survey damage after a severe storm in St. Louis on May 16.

item.title: Sara Duterte Wants Impeachment Trial to Go On, Sees ‘Bloodbath’
item.description: Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte wants her impeachment trial to go ahead, days after her allies outperformed at the midterm election that could add to her bloc of supporters in the Senate.
item.dc:creator: Manolo Serapio Jr

media:content.media:description: Sara Duterte Photographer: Jam STA Rosa/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Australia ‘Up for a Deal’ With the EU After Years of Trade Talks
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said Australia is “up for a deal” with the European Union, sounding a note of cautious optimism after years of trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Karen Leigh

media:content.media:description: Anthony Albanese Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: Beyond Nvidia, Four Things to Know at Asia’s Biggest Tech Show
item.description: Nvidia Corp.’s Jensen Huang headlines the 2025 edition of Asia’s biggest electronics conference, for years a showcase for his company’s cutting-edge AI chips and the companies lining up to buy them. This year, however, the spotlight may well be on another far bigger personality: US President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Vlad Savov, Jane Lanhee Lee

media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang, Nvidia CEO

item.title: Merz Sees No Risk of UniCredit Taking Over Commerzbank Currently
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz currently sees no risk that Italy’s UniCredit SpA will be able to take over Commerzbank AG.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs, Donato Paolo Mancini

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz attends a press conference at Palazzo Chigi, after his meeting with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, in Rome on May 17.
